- Well over at Seasons Eatings,
we have balls for every taste.

Popcorn balls, cheese balls,
rum balls, you name it.

- Wow, my mouth's watering just
thinking about those balls.
(audience laughs)

- It's been years since
I've seen any balls.
(audience laughs)
- Would you like to see my balls now?
(audience laughs)

- Yeah.
- Yeah, whip them out.
- Wow, you have some beautiful balls.
(audience laughs)
- [Host] Hey, what's up guys?
Welcome back to Binging with Babish,

where this week we're taking
a look at some Schweddy Balls.
Now I'm not entirely sure
what was so funny about this sketch,

it seemed like a man trying
to sell some holiday treats
from his family-run company.

I, myself, love balls and I've
got some big, beautiful balls

right here that I think
any friends or family

would be lucky for me to
whip out any time of year,
but especially during the holidays.
So let's see how these guys are made.
First up, popcorn balls.

I'm adding 3 tablespoons of
coconut oil to a big old pot,

along with a little
sprinkle of kosher salt.
And I'm heating that over medium high heat

with a couple of popcorn kernels
in the oil as indicators.

As soon as they pop, we
know our oil is ready to go,
so we're going to take it off the heat.

Add one 1/2 cup of
unpopped popcorn kernels,
toss them around a little bit to make sure

that everybody's nicely
coated in the coconut oil.

Cover and let sit off
the heat for 30 seconds.
This is going to allow the kernels
to come up to temperature gently

so that they pop more
quickly and uniformly.
Now we're placing this back over the heat

and shaking constantly,
preferably with some

oven gloves on like these,
because as the popcorn pops,
it's going to produce a lot of hot steam.
It's also cool to do this with a glass lid
because it's one of the few opportunities
you get to see popcorn visibly popping.
Or maybe I'm just very easy to entertain.
As soon as all the popcorn's been popped,

we're placing it into a
large heat-proof bowl,
salting it generously with kosher salt
while it's still warm so that it sticks.
And then we have to make a sort of caramel
to adhere our popcorn together.

Into a small saucepan,
goes a 1/4 cup of water,

3/4 of a cup of sugar and 3/4
of a cup of light corn syrup.

We're placing this over
medium heat and simmering
until it's reached 235 degrees Fahrenheit,

appropriately known as
the soft ball stage.

At this point, we're taking
the caramel off the heat

and pouring it over our
popcorn in the heat proof bowl.

Now, if you haven't properly
popped all your popcorn,

this is going to be the
moment that you notice.
And these are, unfortunately, unacceptable

for this application cause
nobody wants to crack a tooth
when they're eating a ball.
So while I did have to start over,
all those unpopped kernels
gave me the idea to add some peanuts,

which should bring a nice
nutty flavor to our balls.
Go ahead and stir all this together
until the popcorn is evenly coated.
And then let it sit for three minutes
or until it's still nice and soft,
but cool enough to handle.
Now before handling your balls,
you're gonna want to throw on some gloves
and make sure that they're well-oiled.
As Mr. Schweddy himself suggests,
his balls get plenty of oil.

This is mostly to make
sure that the popcorn

doesn't stick to your hands
as you form it into balls.
Big old balls, about the size of an apple.
Which we're going to arrange
on a parchment-lined baking sheet,
and then drizzle with chocolate.

Popcorn balls are already
pretty messy to eat
and this is just for decoration.

So no need to do anything crazy,
like temper your chocolate.

Just drizzle some short and
curlies on top of your balls

for a pleasant, textural
and flavor sensation
when people put them in their mouths.
There you have it, some super easy festive
and dare I say, manly, popcorn balls.

Next up, an even easier
style ball, the cheese ball.

First we're grading 8
ounces of sharp cheddar
and placing it in the bowl
of a stand mixer or food processor.

Then we're adding 16 ounces
or 2 packages of cream cheese
for creaminess and spreadability.

A few dashes to a few glugs
of your favorite hot sauce,

depending on how spicy
you want your balls.
The greens of two finely chopped scallions

and to give your balls a
little more funky cheesiness,

about two ounces of
finely grated Parmesan.
A big old pinch of kosher salt,

and a few twists of
freshly ground black pepper
and the zest or juice of one lemon,

depending on how tangy
you want your balls.

Mix everybody together or
blitz in the food processor
until it's relatively smooth,
but still has some texture to it.
Once again, generously oil your hands.
It's important these balls not stick
and that they get plenty of oil.
Divide in half and form into two spheres,

which now traditionally
get covered in nuts.
Toasted and cooled pecans,

which we're going to chop
up relatively finely.

Give our naked balls
one last little squeeze
before we roll them around in our nuts.
And there you have it,
a big heaving pair of cheese balls.

Go ahead and cover and
refrigerate these guys
until you're ready to serve.

Next and last, a 90's
holiday classic, rum balls.
Into the bowl of a food processor
goes 8 ounces of vanilla wafer cookies,
about a 1/4 cup of cocoa powder,
4 ounces of toasted and cooled pecans,
and about a 1/2 cup of powdered sugar,
which we're in to process together
until it forms a kind of chunky powder.
Then in a medium bowl, we're combining
1/2 a cup of dark rum, 3 tablespoons
light corn syrup or honey,
and our processed cookie nut mixture.
Go ahead and mix all this together,
adding more rum if necessary
until it forms a firm, stiff, wet mass.
That's how you know it's time for balls.

Once again, grease up those
hands, we want plenty of lube.

And begin rolling the dough
into bite-sized balls.
Arranging them on a parchment paper-lined,
rimmed baking sheet.

Once your more realistically
proportioned balls are formed,

it's time to roll them
thoroughly in either

powdered sugar or cocoa
powder or, hey, why not both,

if you like a little bit of
visual variety in your balls.
And there you have it, rum balls.
Or the things that I used to sneak off

the table at Christmas
parties when I was a kid,
as one of my very first acts of rebellion.

Now Mr. Schweddy delivers
his balls in a sack,

which in this case, I think
it would be impractical
to put these in a ball sack

as they are far too soft,
squishy and delicate.
Instead, let's do a decorative platter.

And this one looks a
little out of proportion.
I'm just going to switch things up here.
There we go, that seems a lot more natural
to me for some reason.
And there you have it, folks.

It's finally time to get
some balls in our mouth.
First up, the popcorn balls,

which are apparently supposed
to be very soft and chewy
and dense, not my favorite.

So the next time I might cook
the caramel to a harder stage.

Go ahead and replace that,
otherwise it just looks violent.
And dig into the cheese balls,
which are my new favorite thing.
There are a myriad of possibilities here.

You could literally shove
any of your favorite cheeses,

cream cheese and vegetables
into a food processor
and make something delicious.
And last but not least, the rum balls.
Little rummy, chocolatey spheres

of chewy, sweet, kind of
crunchy, ball perfection.
I think we've made some balls here
that live up to the Schweddy name.
